content:
IF the index is not in sync with the actual emails stored in mbox file then it may not be able to access the stored email. So if emails are still available then a folder repair should sort out that issue.

  • Right click on Folder and select 'Properties'
  • click on 'Repair Folder'
  • Click on OK

If you have an Anti-Virus and it's allowed to scan profile files and folders and it's allowed to try and Fix anything then it's possible th Anti-Virus has corrupted the file storing the emails. You see, Anti-virus products do not understand that a single text file stores alot of emails not just one bad one. Advise is to make your Thunderbird profile folders exempt from scanning OR at the very least never allow any Anti-Virus product to auto or manual fix anything it may detect in a Thunderbird profile. Anti-Virus would not effect an index file which can explain why it thinks something is there when it is not.

creator: DrDively

content: POP3 is a different set up and it suits me better. Others prefer IMAP. IMAP synchronises a mail server with Thunderbird so you have, in effect, two versions of the same contents. Delete a mail in one, it's deleted in the other - and so on. You have Local Folders that you can bring an email into your computer (to put it crudely) but the server account is 'live' and represents what's on the primary mail server. POP3 downloads emails into the computer and - as I use it - deletes the mail off the server. It also has Local Folders to organise emails in. There are pros and cons for both *but*, although I know a bit about the IMAP set up, I can't definitively give help with it as I use a POP3 account.

Thunderbird, quite suddenly, stopped getting my email; Both on my account and my wife's account at the same ISP.

What is your email provider?

What error message do you get?

Please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.

I carefully entered all the info needed for a new account, following instructions from the agent, then hit the 'Test' button. I got the following message onscreen: "THUNDERBIRD FAILED TO FIND SETTINGS FOR YOUR EMAIL ACCOUNT"

I don't see how creating a new account would solve the original problem of not getting mail. In any case, if the new account wizard fails to find the correct settings for your account you'll have to use manual account configuration. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/manual-account-configuration

We finally tried UNINSTALLING Thunderbird

You're almost certainly wasting your time. All your data such as messages, passwords and user preferences, and changes made while you use Thunderbird, are stored in a special folder called a profile. Your profile folder is stored in a separate place from the Thunderbird program, so that if something ever goes wrong with Thunderbird your information will still be there. It also means that you can uninstall Thunderbird and reinstall without losing your settings and data. It also means re-installing Thunderbird will not fix problems in your profile.

content:
If I were to do all of the below, even if my Trend-Micro AV would allow it (which it doesn't), ...

The suggestions given are generic, and not tailored to the specific anti-virus software you're using.

... I would question why I would even bother to run an AV program at all.

You haven't been told to completely turn off your anti-virus software, so that statement is kind of silly. Following the suggestions would tell your anti-virus software not to mess with Thunderbird mail files, that's it.

Most viruses seem to come in with incoming mail, ...

That's debatable, but I'm not going to argue about it.

... and can be activated just by opening the email, ...

Not true. Opening an email in Thunderbird won't do any harm. Scripting in email messages is forbidden, and it cannot be turned on.

... or opening an attachment in it.

That could potentially be a problem. However, when opening an attachment it gets saved to disk to a temporary directory outside of the Thunderbird profile. So if your anti-virus software is worth the money you paid for it, it would still catch it, and prevent it from doing any harm.

So what I did do was to ADD Exceptions to to the Scan List.

Your list of exceptions won't change a thing. As stated before, you'll have to create an exception for the Thunderbird profile folder, not for the program directory.

After all that ... Thunderbird still will not get my email.

I'm not surprised. In any case, I don't know whether your anti-virus software is causing the problem, but it is quite possible. Even if not, following the suggestions will prevent your anti-virus software to cause Thunderbird mail file corruption, and in the worst case data loss, in the future.

No error displayed

FYI: I finally traced my problem to a program called "KAMO" (Piriform Software Ltd). It is used to change my Internet Footprint (ISP location) and avoid 'tracing' my location by others. Not a bad idea IMO, but some things like my email and Neverwintervault.org didn't like it, and refused connection. To remove EVERYTHING when deleting an application, including configuration files is easy, in Linux at least

Open a terminal, and type "sudo <NAME OF PACKAGE INSTALLER> -Rssn"

What the -R does it removes the application only

-Rss Removes the application itself plus all of its dependencies it alone requires to run, any shared dependencies are left untouched

-Rssn Removes the above and also removes all configuration files.

It's a PITA in Windows. You need to manually delete all the leftover files after removal. If you follow any of the guides for Windows, there is no need to touch your registry, removing anything it the registry will only gain you a few Mb of space. Just because somethings listed there means nothing if the application isn't and has no effect whatsoever on the OS.

The easiest way to find what needs to be removed is 1. Open a command prompt, as Administrator and enter 'whereis Thunderbird' and cd into the appropriate directory and delete the directory or the file. Then enter 'whereis Mozilla' and do the same.

Being the paranoid person I am, I repeat the process a second time, never found anything else, but I'm a belt and suspenders kinda guy.
